You can animate the contents of your iOS or macOS appâ€™s user interface by attaching animations to

In Scene Kit, animation objects represent not only property-based animations, but also animations of geometry data created with external 3D authoring tools and loaded from a scene file. You use the properties of the

object representing a geometry animation to control its timing, monitor its progress, and attach actions for Scene Kit to trigger during the animation. You can attach animations to Scene Kit objects that adopt the
protocol, including nodes, geometries, and materials.
objects support additional methods and properties, listed under Controlling SceneKit Animation Timing, Fading between SceneKit Animations, and Attaching SceneKit Animation Events.

abstract.text: The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.
Render, compose, and animate visual elements.
An interface that allows instances to respond to actions triggered by a Core Animation layer change.
The abstract superclass for animations in Core Animation.
Creates and returns a new
instance.
For animations attached to SceneKit objects, a list of events attached to an animation.
Specifies the default value of the property with the specified key.
Specifies the receiverâ€™s delegate object.
For animations attached to SceneKit objects, the duration for transitioning into the animationâ€™s effect as it begins.
For animations attached to SceneKit objects, the duration for transitioning out of the animationâ€™s effect as it ends.
Creates an animation from a SceneKit animation.
Determines if the animation is removed from the target layerâ€™s animations upon completion.
Specifies whether the value of the property for a given key is archived.
An optional timing function defining the pacing of the animation.
For animations attached to SceneKit objects, a Boolean value that determines whether the animation is evaluated using the scene time or the system time.
Methods your app can implement to respond when animations start and stop.
An object that allows multiple animations to be grouped and run concurrently.
An object that provides basic, single-keyframe animation capabilities for a layer property.
An object that provides keyframe animation capabilities for a layer object.
An object that manages image-based content and allows you to perform animations on that content.
Methods that model a hierarchical timing system, allowing objects to map time between their parent and local time.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
